How do I create a transaction using Verus?

You can create a transaction using Verus by running the `createrawtransaction` command, followed by the inputs and outputs of the transaction. For example:
```
> verus createrawtransaction "[{\"txid\" : \"mytxid\",\"vout\":0}]" "{\"myaddress\":0.01}"
```
This command creates a raw transaction with the specified input and output.

Create a transaction
```bash
> verus createrawtransaction "[{\"txid\" : \"mytxid\",\"vout\":0}]" "{\"myaddress\":0.01}"
```
Sign the transaction, and get back the hex
```bash
> verus signrawtransaction "myhex"
```
Send the transaction (signed hex)
```bash
> verus sendrawtransaction "signedhex"
```
As a json rpc call
```bash
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "sendrawtransaction", "params": ["signedhex"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `signrawtransaction "hexstring" ( [{"txid":"id","vout":n,"scriptPubKey":"hex","redeemScript":"hex"},...] ["privatekey1",...] sighashtype )`
Sign inputs for raw transaction (serialized, hex-encoded).
The second optional argument (may be null) is an array of previous transaction outputs that this transaction depends on but may not yet be in the block chain.
The third optional argument (may be null) is an array of base58-encoded private keys that, if given, will be the only keys used to sign the transaction.

How do I sign a transaction using Verus?

You can sign a transaction using Verus by running the `signrawtransaction` command, followed by the hex-encoded transaction string. For example:
```
> verus signrawtransaction "myhex"
```
This command signs the transaction and returns the signed hex string.

Create a transaction
```bash
> verus createrawtransaction "[{\"txid\" : \"mytxid\",\"vout\":0}]" "{\"myaddress\":0.01}"
```
Sign the transaction, and get back the hex
```bash
> verus signrawtransaction "myhex"
```
Send the transaction (signed hex)
```bash
> verus sendrawtransaction "signedhex"
```

> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "sendrawtransaction", "params": ["signedhex"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `signrawtransaction "hexstring" ( [{"txid":"id","vout":n,"scriptPubKey":"hex","redeemScript":"hex"},...] ["privatekey1",...] sighashtype )`
Sign inputs for raw transaction (serialized, hex-encoded).
The second optional argument (may be null) is an array of previous transaction outputs that this transaction depends on but may not yet be in the block chain.
The third optional argument (may be null) is an array of base58-encoded private keys that, if given, will be the only keys used to sign the transaction.

How do I send a signed transaction using Verus?

You can send a signed transaction using Verus by running the `sendrawtransaction` command, followed by the signed hex string. For example:
```
> verus sendrawtransaction "signedhex"
```
This command sends the signed transaction to the network.

Create a transaction
```bash
> verus createrawtransaction "[{\"txid\" : \"mytxid\",\"vout\":0}]" "{\"myaddress\":0.01}"
```
Sign the transaction, and get back the hex
```bash
> verus signrawtransaction "myhex"

How can I use JSON RPC to send a signed transaction using Verus?

You can use JSON RPC to send a signed transaction using Verus by sending a JSON RPC request to the Verus server. For example:
```
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "sendrawtransaction", "params": ["signedhex"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```
This command sends a JSON RPC request to the Verus server to send the signed transaction.

Create a transaction
```bash
> verus createrawtransaction "[{\"txid\" : \"mytxid\",\"vout\":0}]" "{\"myaddress\":0.01}"
```
Sign the transaction, and get back the hex

What is the purpose of the `signrawtransaction` command in Verus?

The `signrawtransaction` command in Verus is used to sign inputs for a raw transaction. It takes a hex-encoded transaction string as input, and returns the signed hex string. The command can also take optional arguments, such as an array of previous transaction outputs that this transaction depends on, and an array of base58-encoded private keys that will be used to sign the transaction.

Create a transaction
```bash
> verus createrawtransaction "[{\"txid\" : \"mytxid\",\"vout\":0}]" "{\"myaddress\":0.01}"
```
Sign the transaction, and get back the hex
```bash
> verus signrawtransaction "myhex"
```
Send the transaction (signed hex)
```bash
> verus sendrawtransaction "signedhex"
```
As a json rpc call
```bash
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "sendrawtransaction", "params": ["signedhex"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `signrawtransaction "hexstring" ( [{"txid":"id","vout":n,"scriptPubKey":"hex","redeemScript":"hex"},...] ["privatekey1",...] sighashtype )`
Sign inputs for raw transaction (serialized, hex-encoded).
The second optional argument (may be null) is an array of previous transaction outputs that this transaction depends on but may not yet be in the block chain.
The third optional argument (may be null) is an array of base58-encoded private keys that, if given, will be the only keys used to sign the transaction.
